snippet.textDisplay:
I've just seen the movie. What a film. If a masterpiece is informative, intelligent, clever & gripping from start to finish. Not to mention deeply moving, then 1917 is a masterpiece.
It's the 1st World War movie, from the British perspective, that I've been waiting for.
snippet.textOriginal:
I've just seen the movie. What a film. If a masterpiece is informative, intelligent, clever & gripping from start to finish. Not to mention deeply moving, then 1917 is a masterpiece. 
It's the 1st World War movie, from the British perspective, that I've been waiting for.

snippet.textDisplay: If Hollywood want to cut down on lost revenue due to illegal streaming, the onus is on them to make films such as 1917 - films that are immersive, powerful, and that demand to be experienced on a big screen in a dark room. 1917 should be nominated for many awards and in a just world, it would win whatever it is nominated for.

snippet.textDisplay:
Spoilers



That initial 15-20 minute sequence when they go over the top, across no mans land, into the german trench culminating with the trip wire going off and having to escape was a pure masterclass in building and releasing tension. The rest of the film is very good but that was the standout moment for me.
snippet.textOriginal:
*Spoilers*

snippet.textDisplay: Just came back from seeing "1917."  An amazing film!  Compelling in every way.  I highly recommend it to anyone interested in either good movies or the history of World War I.   Up there with "Paths of Glory."
snippet.textOriginal: Just came back from seeing "1917."  An amazing film!  Compelling in every way.  I highly recommend it to anyone interested in either good movies or the history of World War I.   Up there with "Paths of Glory."

snippet.textDisplay: Continuous shot is gimmick. Great costume /set design /cinematography, but crappy screenplay because cliches and nonsense. Why not drop message from biplane? Only send 2 men to save 1,600? Storming trench would have been suicide if manned. Rolling stone 1981 is now biplane coming at you. Zero emotional impact. Saving Private Gallipoli. Hollywood is out of new ideas and must recycle.
snippet.textOriginal: Continuous shot is gimmick. Great costume /set design /cinematography, but crappy screenplay because cliches and nonsense. Why not drop message from biplane? Only send 2 men to save 1,600? Storming trench would have been suicide if manned. Rolling stone 1981 is now biplane coming at you. Zero emotional impact. Saving Private Gallipoli. Hollywood is out of new ideas and must recycle.

snippet.textDisplay:
Saw this at the weekend, it was absolutely brilliant.

It was intense, emotional, beautifully shot and the one take cinematography (there are cuts but cleverly hidden) was a technical marvel.

I had to decompress for a few moments after watching it because I did feel part of it, and I was emotionally drained, in a good way.

Simply a must see, especially on the big screen.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Powerful and deeply effecting. As a grandson of a Lance corporal who fought his way through the entire war I was thinking of him as I watched. I wept in places. Just being sentimental? No I don't think so the film was a journey into the reality of the Great War.  I thought Journey's End (mentioned below), whilst another fine piece of cinema, failed to engage me in the way that 1917 did.
snippet.textOriginal: Powerful and deeply effecting. As a grandson of a Lance corporal who fought his way through the entire war I was thinking of him as I watched. I wept in places. snippet.textDisplay:
Why cant we get a world war two movie set in Yugoslavia? With English speaking actors and actresses. You dont have the unspoken issue one set in China or Japan would have ie white well known big stars can be in it rather than East Asians no one has heard off (yes I know it's unfair but that's the way it is).

And it be both fresh and informative. Unlike France/UK/Russia/USA vs Germany/Japan youd have people who knew each other fighting each other. Serbian people killed by their Croatian neighbours. The Ustache (Croatian fascists) where ISIS on steroids even Himmler felt sick at what they did. The potential is limitless. I dont know why war movies have to be so bloody parochial.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: So... a General personally briefs two Lance Corporals (NCOs) on a task to intercept a Battalion. Have I missed something? Isn’t this an absolutely incredibly absurd plot? Surreal. In practice a General wouldn’t talk to an NCO, let alone give then direct orders. Wouldn’t the General’s staff officers instruct a commissioned officer, by paper order or phone (if the lines were ok) to take a patrol of about 6 men to do the job. The line about the NCOs’ personal links wouldn’t have mattered at all. And the fact that it’s a Battalion they’re intercepting is important - that’s a very substantial force and their loss might have cost the General his job. And 1,600 men is a overly large Battalion? Weren’t they about 1,000 incl. all support staff? Or did they expand by 1917? Yes, individual soldiers used as messengers were a universal feature of WW1. But this is a fantasy plot?
snippet.textOriginal: So... a General personally briefs two Lance Corporals (NCOs) on a task to intercept a Battalion. Have I missed something? Isn’t this an absolutely incredibly absurd plot? snippet.textDisplay: Just when I thought all hope for film was lost, I saw Joker. Couldn't believe how awesome it was. Thought, "yep, that's the last decent movie i'll ever see" . Saw this Yesterday, had no idea it was a film, knew nothing about it. And now i almost think it's better than Joker. It was amazing, so incredibly well shot, so real, so engrossing, you feel as if you're in a real war-nothing about it feels fake. Marvellous movie. One of the greats for sure. 10/10. WOW.

snippet.textDisplay:
I thought cinema died in 1993 with the death of Federico Fellini. This movie gives me hope that I actually was wrong.

The writer/director is cruelly squeezing our souls dry each and every second, for two long hours.

It's amazing how Sir Sam Mendes sublimates the horror of death (over the horse's carcass I actually hold my breath!!!) into the pure heavenly bliss of the final moments under that fabulous Axis Mundi tree. In those moments the movie becomes a heartbreaking paean to family and our inalienable humanity.

Thank you, Sir Sam Mendes, for destroying the mystique of "glamour and honor". Thank you for saying "It's just a piece of tin that nobody cares about".

The movie is like a stroll in the famous Peter Bruegel painting "The Triumph of Death".

The days of the action (6 and 7 April 1917) are very mysterious.

All I can say is that 6 April 1917 is the day the USA declared war to Germany in WWI... And 7 April is the day most historians accept as the day of the Crucifixion ( year 30 AD)...

All the movie seems to be under the hallmark of the famous Russian director Andrei Tarkowsky...

All in all, it's good to have a trumpet player as wife...
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Just saw 1917 today. Amazing on several levels.  Cinematography is amazing...I don't know how they shot many scenes. Overt messages, of course, about the atrocities of war and the responsibility of duty are there. But am I wrong to think there was a more subtle, but overall more important, message about the importance of family, punctuated throughout the film and emphasized in the night scene with the baby? (No spoilers!) It makes me wonder what is Corporal Schofield's back story, more specifically what is/was his relationship like with his mother....as I believe this adds to his sense of duty to see his mission through. This may not be a movie everyone finds entertaining, but how anyone could give the movie a negative review is beyond me.
snippet.textOriginal: Just saw 1917 today. Amazing on several levels.  Cinematography is amazing...I don't know how they shot many scenes. Overt messages, of course, about the atrocities of war and the responsibility of duty are there. But am I wrong to think there was a more subtle, but overall more important, message about the importance of family, punctuated throughout the film and emphasized in the night scene with the baby? (No spoilers!) It makes me wonder what is Corporal Schofield's back story, more specifically what is/was his relationship like with his mother....as I believe this adds to his sense of duty to see his mission through. This may not be a movie everyone finds entertaining, but how anyone could give the movie a negative review is beyond me.

snippet.textDisplay: This is one of the best movies of all time.  Everything is simple but perfectly executed.  The one shot transitions work so well.  Just a constant feeling of dread.  You know the enemy is there, you just don't know when they are going to encounter the protagonist (and by extension us the viewer due to the way it is filmed).  I shed a few tears.
snippet.textOriginal: This is one of the best movies of all time.  Everything is simple but perfectly executed.  The one shot transitions work so well.  Just a constant feeling of dread.  You know the enemy is there, you just don't know when they are going to encounter the protagonist (and by extension us the viewer due to the way it is filmed).  I shed a few tears.

snippet.textDisplay: What I loved most about it was the futility aspect of the war, he managed to stop the attack but to what? He didn’t end the war, his heroic actions was a mere stay of execution, the men in the battalion still would’ve had died, his actions were a mere drop in the water of the countless amount of soldiers who lost their lives fruitlessly for a seemingly un-winnable war

snippet.textDisplay: Just seen the film - loved it, but can someone please tell these ‘woke’directors British Army regiments were not colour integrated in WW1 The scene with the Sikh soldier was fine - but having black soldiers in the final scene was simply incorrect - Commonwealth and non-white units performed absolutely superbly - just look at the VC’s won by the Gurkhas - but not in this scenario-  show their heroism in the historically accurate setting and do their deeds justice

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry,  but I left the Imax underwhelmed, maybe  I was expecting too much given the reviews.  Yes, the cinematography was good, but the set scenes were mostly implausible. For me, it started with the explosion in the underground gallery, after which it got more and more implausible as the film moved on. I know my comment bucks this thread, but that's just my personal take on 1917 the movie. I think Saving Private Ryan was a better film.
snippet.textOriginal: Sorry,  but I left the Imax underwhelmed, maybe  I was expecting too much given the reviews.  Yes, the cinematography was good, but the set scenes were mostly implausible. For me, it started with the explosion in the underground gallery, after which it got more and more implausible as the film moved on. I know my comment bucks this thread, but that's just my personal take on 1917 the movie. I think Saving Private Ryan was a better film.

snippet.textDisplay:
Bloodless? He did say bloodless? It's been over a hundred years and the worst accounts are still shied away from.
Accounts of men sleeping in fetid pools stained by chemical weapons and toxic debris, surrounded and filled by thousands of bodies (and parts thereof) that can't retrieved where men have to shit where they lie because they don't want to die. (in the abstract landscapes of Passchendaele)
Accounts of machine gunners carving holes into the piles of dead with their bullets to get a clear shot, with the germans being so relentless in their charge to death. (Liège?)
WW1 should be a sick gore flick. Why isn't someone making the surreal hyperbole of this already surreal violence?

I'll probably like this movie anyway, so whatever I guess.
snippet.textOriginal:

Accounts of men sleeping in fetid pools stained by chemical weapons and toxic debris, surrounded and filled by thousands of bodies (and parts thereof) that can't retrieved where men have to shit where they lie because they don't want to die. (in the abstract landscapes of Passchendaele)
Accounts of machine gunners carving holes into the piles of dead with their bullets to get a clear shot, with the germans being so relentless in their charge to death. (Liège?)
WW1 should be a sick gore flick. Why isn't someone making the surreal hyperbole of this already surreal violence? 

I'll probably like this movie anyway, so whatever I guess.

snippet.textDisplay:
I used to Watch Mark Kermode on TV in the 1990's when I was a teenager. I remember when he presented the Top 100 movies back then, voted by the British public in some survey or other.
When Star Wars (1977) won, I cheered at the TV and he was so pissed off! LMAO!
Ah well. It's nice to see he's still going.

Ah well. It's nice to see he's still going.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wrote the script and picked the cast for this film around the time I wrote Knives Out.  Sam Mendes, like Todd Bunzl, Martin Scorsese, Rian Johnson, Brad Pitt, Jeff Bezos, George Lucas and Taika Waititi are not fond of accrediting the original writer especially when Bezos has a grudge and Lucas fears my surname as he is a tight fisted Palpatine level Satanist.

I wanted Deakins as soon as I saw the Bladerunner sequel and wanted a Children of Men style take in WW1 trench warfare as that would be both an artistic triumph and a crowd pleaser for all the old musty farts in movie awards and artistic circles spending government funds on what they subjectively deem "art".

I wrote the script with reference to William Blake and Phillip Schofield as influential men, the first to me was a mad genius and the second was a name that carries weight for working age adults.  The cast were men who have acted well or stuck out to me as excellent character actors that I could write specifically for.

The key point to prove I wrote this script is that I studied Blake and WW1 poetry in my AQA A Level in English Literature in Bedford College around the time I wrote There Will Be Blood and not too long before I wrote the rest of my War on Terror trilogy of Iron Man 1 and The Dark Knight before a ten year hiatus that ended with:

Joker an Origin Story and The Irishman as first a recalling of my tragic bitter life experiences as an Autistic savant be it on the bus, dreaming of acceptance, longing for a positive father figure and the nihilistic disaffection I was trapped in.  The Irishman was all of that with tips to Godfather, my work history, humour and tragedy.

I also wrote Ad Astra, Booksmart and Uncut Gems, not that anyone will believe a gentile in the heady world of ultra pro-Zionist media as they drift ignorantly along echo chambers of sycophantic geriatric worship for semi-literate Scorsese and the exulted engorged ego's of wrinkly hard headed Hollywood Heavyweights.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wrote the script and picked the cast for this film around the time I wrote Knives Out.  Sam Mendes, like Todd Bunzl, Martin Scorsese, Rian Johnson, Brad Pitt, Jeff Bezos, George Lucas and Taika Waititi are not fond of accrediting the original writer especially when Bezos has a grudge and Lucas fears my surname as he is a tight fisted Palpatine level Satanist.

I wanted Deakins as soon as I saw the Bladerunner sequel and wanted a Children of Men style take in WW1 trench warfare as that would be both an artistic triumph and a crowd pleaser for all the old musty farts in movie awards and artistic circles spending government funds on what they subjectively deem "art".

I wrote the script with reference to William Blake and Phillip Schofield as influential men, the first to me was a mad genius and the second was a name that carries weight for working age adults.  The cast were men who have acted well or stuck out to me as excellent character actors that I could write specifically for.

The key point to prove I wrote this script is that I studied Blake and WW1 poetry in my AQA A Level in English Literature in Bedford College around the time I wrote There Will Be Blood and not too long before I wrote the rest of my War on Terror trilogy of Iron Man 1 and The Dark Knight before a ten year hiatus that ended with:

Joker an Origin Story and The Irishman as first a recalling of my tragic bitter life experiences as an Autistic savant be it on the bus, dreaming of acceptance, longing for a positive father figure and the nihilistic disaffection I was trapped in.  The Irishman was all of that with tips to Godfather, my work history, humour and tragedy.

I also wrote Ad Astra, Booksmart and Uncut Gems, not that anyone will believe a gentile in the heady world of ultra pro-Zionist media as they drift ignorantly along echo chambers of sycophantic geriatric worship for semi-literate Scorsese and the exulted engorged ego's of wrinkly hard headed Hollywood Heavyweights.

snippet.textDisplay:
Few things I don't like: (i) the media narrative that the film is 'one continuous shot'. It's not. (ii) Mendes seems to have had a Bond hangover -an ordinary British Tommy is not James Bond (iii) the 'milk' coincidence (iv) the singing scene - as if that would happen! Leave the beautiful vocal for the credits

Loved the tunnel scene and the village scene.

snippet.textDisplay: Brilliant, of course it ... but am I allowed two gripes. One is the make-up of the final 10 minutes ... not a scratch on his face, after all that adventure through the carnage of war, almost porcelain-like, and what happened to the wound on his neck?; and secondly, why oh why does the casting director insist on at least one well known actor (sorry Colin F) to carry an important element, when this film should have been awash with relative unknowns (as the two young protagonists are.) But there are so many sublime moments of absolute class - direction, action, lighting, and an astonishing production design. 4.5 stars, for the two blips mentioned above.
snippet.textOriginal: Brilliant, of course it ... but am I allowed two gripes. One is the make-up of the final 10 minutes ... not a scratch on his face, after all that adventure through the carnage of war, almost porcelain-like, and what happened to the wound on his neck?; and secondly, why oh why does the casting director insist on at least one well known actor (sorry Colin F) to carry an important element, when this film should have been awash with relative unknowns (as the two young protagonists are.) But there are so many sublime moments of absolute class - direction, action, lighting, and an astonishing production design. 4.5 stars, for the two blips mentioned above.

snippet.textDisplay: This movie has everything. Its profound, enlightening, has well developed characters, it immerses the audience and makes you feel like you're in the trenches with all the characters and is incredibly moving and intense. The messages conveyed are nuanced yet subtle but also profound. This movie is a great road and psychological war thriller film. It's a modern classic and one of the best war films that I've ever seen as well as one of the best movies of the year. This masterpiece is filmmaking at it's finest.
snippet.textOriginal: This movie has everything. Its profound, enlightening, has well developed characters, it immerses the audience and makes you feel like you're in the trenches with all the characters and is incredibly moving and intense. The messages conveyed are nuanced yet subtle but also profound. This movie is a great road and psychological war thriller film. It's a modern classic and one of the best war films that I've ever seen as well as one of the best movies of the year. This masterpiece is filmmaking at it's finest.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nick Randall-Smith
1 second ago
My great uncle (Sgt George Musson RE) was awarded the Distinguished Conduct Medal and mentioned in The London Gazette for delivering a vital message in 1918. After being told it was almost a suicide mission he rode his motorcycle under direct fire to take a message from his battalion to the divisional HQ, on the way his motorcycle got a puncture so he had to stop and fix it, all the time he was constantly being shot at; with the puncture repaired he continued on and delivered the note to his HQ. He was then given another message and asked to take back to his battalion, he was shot at all the way back again as well. The Distinguished Conduct Medal (DCM) was the army's second level gallantry award for non-commissioned soldiers, the only medal for an act of gallantry ranked higher was the Victoria Cross. I must go and see this film.

My great uncle (Sgt George Musson RE) was awarded the Distinguished Conduct Medal and mentioned in The London Gazette for delivering a vital message in 1918.  After being told it was almost a suicide mission he rode his motorcycle under direct fire to take a message from his battalion to the divisional HQ,  on the way his motorcycle got a puncture so he had to stop and fix it, all the time he was constantly being shot at;  with the puncture repaired he continued on and delivered the note to his HQ.  He was then given another message and asked to take back to his  battalion, he was shot at all the way back again as well.  The Distinguished Conduct Medal (DCM) was the army's second level gallantry award for non-commissioned soldiers, the only medal for an act of gallantry ranked higher was the Victoria Cross.  I must go and see this film.

snippet.textDisplay: I’m 61 retired U.S. Army and amateur military historian. Movie was well done. I did feel that the Germans were dumped on. However they may deserve it. Not my call. German pilot kills his rescuer. Germans  cut down fruit trees and kill civilian livestock. Drunken puking German in movie. Boobytraps by Germans in tunnel complex. Anyway, will not be a popular movie shown in German theaters.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wish I could ask Mark: If you hate war movies, should you see this?
The genre is so boring to me and I've never enjoyed things like "The Longest Day" or "The Battle of Iwo Jima." But I like Sam Mendes as a filmmaker and seeing it get so many nominations, I feel obliged to watch.
But I also don't want to go to the movies feeling like I"m partaking in a chore, not a piece of entertainment.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wish I could ask Mark: If you hate war movies, should you see this? 
The genre is so boring to me and I've never enjoyed things like "The Longest Day" or "The Battle of Iwo Jima." But I like Sam Mendes as a filmmaker and seeing it get so many nominations, I feel obliged to watch.
 But I also don't want to go to the movies feeling like I"m partaking in a chore, not a piece of entertainment.

snippet.textDisplay: Am I mad? I appreciated the directing, the cinematography 1000% and the “one shot” thing was an amazing feat to pull off. But for me I thought it was okay? snippet.textDisplay: From Mark’s description the film borrows  structure and  themes from The Divine Comedy. Not only in the Homeric journey to the underworld parallel and notion of journey through Hell to redemption but also the symmetry where the beginning mirrors the end (DC is structured in a similar fashion).  Looking forward to it.
